I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA), Updating the Revised Strategic 
Transport Plan (RSTP) for Dhaka, will help enhance planning capacity and coordination in the 
urban transport sector in the city of Dhaka and support the Road Transport and Highways Division, 
Ministry of Road Transport and Bridges (MORTB), the executing agency, to strengthen its 
planning capacity. 
 
2.  The TA is included in the country operations business plan of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) for Bangladesh, 2021–2023. The objectives of the TA are aligned with the plan’s 
strategic objectives and priorities: (i) to ease infrastructure constraints in key sectors, such as 
energy, transport, and urban development; and (ii) to address institutional capacity constraints 
and improve governance.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh—together with parts of the adjacent cities and 
districts  of  Gazipur,  Manikganj,  Munshiganj,  Narayanganj,  and  Narshindi—constitutes  the 
jurisdiction of Rajdhani Unnayan Kartripakkha (RAJUK), the authority mandated to plan land use 
and implement urban development projects over an area of 1,528 square kilometers. This wider 
area surrounding Dhaka is the center of Bangladesh’s economic activity, contributing nearly 40% 
of the gross national product, and attracts migrants from other regions of Bangladesh in search of 
business  and  employment  opportunities. 2  Its  population  has  increased  rapidly,  reaching 
15.9 million or about 10% of the country’s entire population in 2011, and is projected to grow 
further to 26.3 million by 2035. The city’s population grew 3.9% annually from 2001 to 2011, well 
above the national growth rate of 1.4%.3 
4.  Transport challenges in Dhaka. Despite its rapid population and economic growth and 
corresponding increase in traffic demand, Dhaka still relies heavily on road transport. Of the 
15 million daily trips per day, an estimated 47% are by bus and 14% by car. The number of 
vehicles in Dhaka has increased steadily—about 140,000 vehicles were added in 2017, including 
 
about 20,000 private cars.4 Traffic volume in Dhaka exceeds the road capacity by 20% on average 
 
during peak hours, and by more than 100% on particular sections in the city center.5 The bus 
system is operated by the publicly owned Bangladesh Road Transport Corporation (BRTC) and 
a large number of private operators. Although bus is the predominant mode of public transport in 
Dhaka, the bus system is inefficient, unreliable, and unsafe.6 Rail-based public transport is limited 
to Bangladesh Railways within Dhaka, with only two commuter service lines carrying a total of

2 
about 25,000 passengers per day.7 The first mass rapid transit (MRT) network is still under 
 
development.8 The inadequate supply of transport services is compounded by a lack of growth 
management and consequent rapid, uncontrolled urbanization. Dhaka is among the most densely 
populated cities in the world, with 11,094 people per square kilometer. The built-up area increased 
by 20% during 1989–2010, resulting in a general worsening of living conditions, slum growth, and 
increased incidence of flash flooding (footnote 3). 
 
5.  The economy of Bangladesh has grown rapidly at an annual average rate of 6.5% 
between  2005  and  2019,  and  the  country’s  economic  structure  has  transformed  from  an 
agriculture orientation to value-adding manufacturing and service industries. Dhaka remains the 
industrial and commercial center, attracting mass migration from other parts of the country, and 
increasing per capita income is enabling more of its residents to buy cars. The economic loss 
caused by traffic congestion is estimated at about 7% of gross domestic product.9 There is an 
urgent need to increase the supply of transport services in Dhaka and provide efficient transport 
connections between Dhaka and the surrounding areas, while controlling the worsening traffic 
problems within the center in the short-term to enhance the productivity and sustainability of 
Bangladesh’s capital. To meet this goal, the government needs to accelerate investment in the 
urban transport sector in Dhaka through efficient urban transport planning and well-integrated 
land development plans. 
 
6.  Institutional and regulatory framework. The institutional and regulatory framework of 
Dhaka’s transport sector has undergone reforms to address the need to develop large-scale 
infrastructure. The Dhaka Transport Coordination Board, established in 2001, was enhanced into 
the Dhaka Transport Coordination Authority (DTCA) in 2012. The DTCA is tasked with overseeing 
effective and efficient planning, development, and coordination among the growing number of 
transport projects, especially the new MRT and bus rapid transit (BRT) systems proposed in the 
RSTP.10 
 
7.  However, serious challenges remain: (i) the DTCA lacks sufficient staffing to serve as the 
apex transport planning agency in Dhaka, and personnel are not adequately trained in urban 
transport policy formulation or project planning, especially in crucial areas such as transport 
modeling, traffic engineering, and urban planning;11 (ii) the DTCA struggles to effectively exercise 
its planning and coordination mandate because of its highly polarized structure consisting of a 
large number of transport agencies or within RAJUK, and unclear delineation of authority among 
them, resulting in inconsistency between transport planning and land use planning; 12 and (iii) the 
decision-making procedure is highly inefficient, with the project screening process taking months 
in the absence of an efficient screening framework. 
 
8.  Government’s urban transport strategy.  The government’s Eighth Five-Year Plan 
prioritizes  addressing  major  institutional  constraints  to  identifying  and  implementing

transformational transport projects that efficiently allocate resources. A top priority in urban 
transport is reducing traffic congestion and developing an integrated system for supporting 
sustainable urban development.13 In Dhaka, the Dhaka Transport Coordination Board formulated 
the Strategic Transport Plan for Dhaka in 1998 with the assistance of the World Bank. Approved 
by the government in 2005, the plan included an urban transport policy (2004–2024), which 
identified priority issues such as improvement of MRTs, development of urban expressways, and 
institutional reforms.14 
 
9.  Revised Strategic Transport Plan. The government formulated the RSTP in 2016 as an 
urban transport master plan for Dhaka with a 20-year planning horizon, with support from the 
Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA). The RSTP intends to ensure mobility and access 
to vital urban services by providing safe and equitable transport systems that use efficient and 
sustainable public transport modes, and are integrated with land use and urban development. 
The RSTP identifies six distinct public transport corridors with high passenger traffic demand that 
connect  Dhaka’s  central  business  district  with  surrounding  satellite  regional  centers.  To 
accommodate the projected high demand, the RSTP proposes five MRT lines and two BRT lines 
to be completed by 2035 along those corridors.15 
 
10.  While the RSTP has provided a clear vision for the sector through the development of 
MRTs, the following limitations are evident following 5 years of implementation: (i) the baseline 
survey data and information have gradually become outdated, and the priority project list also 
requires updating as various agencies plan new projects, some of which may not be fully 
consistent  with  the  current  RSTP  guiding  policies  or  priorities; (ii)  the  RSTP  gives  limited 
consideration to multimodal integration that is crucial for improving the efficiency of the overall 
urban transport network; connectivity between intracity and intercity public transport services 
should also be given more attention to help disperse Dhaka’s population to adjacent regional 
centers;  and  (iii)  the  RSTP  focuses  heavily  on  physical  infrastructure  solutions  and  lacks 
(a) strong proposals for effective short-term measures to manage or control traffic demand, (b) a 
specific policy and analysis of opportunities for transit-oriented development and value capture 
financing as tools for sustainable infrastructure financing and promoting integrated land and 
transport planning, and (c) in-depth analysis into public–private partnerships. 
 
11.  Alignment with ADB’s Strategy 2030. The TA will contribute to tackling climate change, 
building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental sustainability by making 
climate and disaster resilience the key consideration in the urban transport master plan for the 
capital of one of the most climate change-affected countries. The TA will also provide training on 
low carbon transport solutions for Dhaka’s urban transport officials. The TA will also contribute to 
making cities more livable by supporting the formulation of an urban transport master plan 
integrated with land use plans, and thereby promote the well-organized development of Dhaka 
and its adjacent regional centers. Finally, the TA will contribute to strengthening governance and 
institutional capacity by assisting the DTCA in planning capacity building programs as well as 
streamlining the government’s urban transport project screening process. These improvements 
will help accelerate investments in critical transport infrastructure in a more effective, efficient, 
and accountable manner. 
 
12.  ADB’s contribution to Dhaka’s transport sector. ADB’s country partnership strategy

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
13.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: delivery of urban transport services in Dhaka 
improved and integrated.19 The TA will have the following outcome: planning and programming 
of urban transport services in Dhaka improved.20 To meet the rapidly increasing transport demand 
and promote sustainable urban development in Dhaka, the RSTP as the urban transport master 
plan needs to be immediately updated and used strategically in Dhaka’s transport planning 
process. Specifically, potential transport projects need to be aligned with the RSTP’s urban 
transport policy, and incorporated into the plan to ensure the entire urban transport sector 
investment program is efficient. This must become mandatory for all future transport projects in 
Dhaka to speed up decision-making regarding sector investments. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
14.  Output 1: Revised Strategic Transport Plan for Dhaka updated. The TA aims to 
update the existing transport policies and strategies in Dhaka in light of current challenges and 
new opportunities to improve transport sector service delivery. The TA also aims to develop an 
updated and prioritized list of projects to ensure alignment between programming and the updated 
RSTP. The TA will deliver the following: 
(i)  Propose a TA implementation framework for smooth coordination and effective 
incorporation of feedback of agencies in the RSTP updating process, and ensure 
the technical quality of the update.21 
(ii)  Review the RSTP and other relevant plans related to land use and transport 
development in Dhaka and identify key areas in the RSTP in need of updating. 
(iii)  Conduct traffic and public transport surveys and a transport infrastructure inventory

model. Update the transport demand forecast using the modified model. 
(v)  Prepare scenarios for a future modal split in Dhaka and test various options in the 
strategic transport model. Use the model outputs to identify priorities to respond to 
Dhaka’s congestion challenges and, accordingly, review and update the urban 
transport strategy. The focus should be on (a) enforcing a trunk-feeder transport 
network, with the MRTs as the main modality; (b) incorporating the projects not 
included in the RSTP; (c) integrating multimodal transport, traffic management 
measures, road safety, and informal public transport modes into the RSTP; and 
(d) giving consideration to nonmotorized transit vehicles and pedestrians. 
(vi)  Propose effective use of applicable innovative and digital solutions for improving 
transport services. 
(vii)  Assess opportunities for transit-oriented development along the alignment of the 
proposed MRTs. 
(viii)  Explore and propose alternative funding options for urban transport projects such 
as public–private partnerships and value capture financing.23 
(ix)  Review and update the urban transport development road map, with a list of 
indicative projects for each subsector of urban transport. 
(x)  Update the implementation program based on an updated priority project list for 
short-term, medium-term, and long-term timeframes. 
(xi)  Prepare a list of output requirements for up to three priority projects. 
(xii)  Finalize the updated RSTP covering items (ii)–(xi). 
 
15.  Output 2: Planning capacity in urban transport sector of Dhaka enhanced. The TA 
aims to improve the capacity of the urban transport sector in Dhaka, focusing on the DTCA to 
exercise its planning, programming, and coordination functions under the updated RSTP. The TA 
will also support the review and drafting of a law to accelerate programming and investment 
decision-making in the sector through enhanced use of the updated RSTP. The TA will undertake 
the following activities: 
(i)  Identify stakeholder land use planning and transport agencies, and review their 
mandates, functions, organization, and activities. 
(ii)  Review the DTCA’s mandate and functions and propose institutional reforms to 
increase urban transport planning efficiency, including human resources planning 
and plan enhancement. 
(iii)  Formulate a planning capacity-building program for the DTCA in areas such as 
urban planning, transport modeling, participatory planning, and traffic engineering, 
and conduct such training.24 
(iv)  Propose a mechanism and/or framework to establish the updated RSTP as a 
project screening tool for urban transport projects in Dhaka on the basis of the draft 
law prepared by the DTCA. 
(v)  Support the DTCA in obtaining  government endorsement for the mechanism 
and/or  framework  in  (iv)  by  assisting  in  the  finalization  of  the  relevant  draft

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $4,153,950, of which (i) $1,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 7), and (ii) $2,000,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) and administered by ADB.26 
The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2.27 
 
17.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of (i) counterpart staff; 
(ii) access to relevant data and information; (iii) staff time to review outputs of consultants; 
(iv) necessary coordination with stakeholder agencies; (v) support for organizing committee 
meetings, workshops, and training; (vi) required safety and security measures; (vii) vehicles for 
counterpart staff and individual consultants to support the project implementation unit; and 
(viii) other in-kind contributions.

19.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.29 An international consulting firm will be recruited through the quality- 
and cost-based selection with a 90:10 quality–cost ratio. In addition, one individual international 
consultant and one national consultant will be recruited to support the DTCA in ensuring quality 
control of the firm’s consultant outputs and efficient project implementation. The consultants will 
procure software, including for developing a traffic demand forecast model. 
 
20.  Cofinancier requirements. Project records are to be updated quarterly in eOperations 
following ADB’s Project Performance Monitoring.30 The Embassy of Japan and JICA shall (i) be 
informed about project progress, milestones, and outcomes; and (ii) discuss when major changes 
in scope and objectives are required. A TA completion report will be prepared no later than 1 year 
after TA completion to document actual cumulative inputs, outputs and outcomes, and lessons 
through the TA implementation period, and this will be shared by ADB’s Sustainable Development 
and Climate Change Department (SDCC) with the Embassy of Japan and JICA. A record of 
Japanese visibility measures must also be included in the TA completion report. The SDCC 
should be provided with a copy (e.g., printed or electronic) of knowledge products to be delivered 
under the JFPR TA and ensure that Japanese visibility is reflected.31 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
the equivalent of $2,000,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction; and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a 
grant basis to the Government of Bangladesh for Updating the Revised Strategic Transport Plan 
for Dhaka, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
